title-group.article-title: Bank Discount, Coupon Equivalent, and Compound Yields: Comment

abstract.p: A recent paper in "Financial Management" claims to correct a theoretical inconsistency and serious bias present in the customary formulas for calculating the coupon equivalent yield of a short-term discounted security. However, this purported inconsistency and bias stem from the authors' particular interpretation of these formulas. Applied correctly, the customary formulas do facilitate meaningful yield comparisons. Moreover, I show that the proposed alternative formula suffers from some serious shortcomings, particularly when it is applied to discounted securities that mature in no more than six months. However, I point out an inconsistency in securities industry practice that was overlooked by the authors and show that because of this inconsistency, their alternative formula might nevertheless prove useful in calculating the coupon equivalent yield of a discounted note that matures in more than six months.
